AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: The only customer-facing AI message (12/16) is broadly consistent with the engineering update (fix planned for next release). No clear factual errors, broken templates, irrelevant troubleshooting, or unmet promises are evidenced in the ticket transcript.
evidence: [2025-12-16T11:23:02+00:00] AI to customer: "...issue...has successfully addressed... This fix is slated for release next weekend."
Engineering issue closure note: "We have made fixes in the agent... The fixed agent will be released next weekend. No changes in exinda are required."

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: No evidence the customer requested a human and was denied, nor repeated requests for the same information. The customer had two short messages, then the case was escalated and later updated.
evidence: Customer: "please pass this to engineering" (no request for a human beyond escalation).

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Support did not ask for already-provided artifacts or repeat the same troubleshooting after the customer said it was done. The customer provided context and requested escalation; support ultimately escalated and communicated status.
evidence: Support escalation confirmation: "We have escalated this to our Engineering team for review."

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: There is a clear gap of more than 3 calendar days between the customer's messages requesting engineering escalation and the first support response confirming escalation.
evidence: [2025-11-12T15:24:17+00:00] Customer: "Please move this ticket to Engineering for fixing."
[2025-11-30T14:53:32+00:00] Support (Randall Shawver): "We have escalated this to our Engineering team for review."

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: The customer explicitly requested closure and support closed accordingly. No pending unanswered question/request remained at closure.
evidence: [2025-12-17T15:02:18+00:00] Customer: "thanks, we can close this ticket"
[2025-12-17T15:02:30+00:00] Support: "...we are closing this ticket as requested."

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: The ticket does not explicitly indicate P1/SEV1/Critical status, outage, or SLA/time-critical language. While the issue could block upgrades due to disk space, there is no explicit high-severity designation meeting the detection criteria.
evidence: Customer describes impact: "...occupy too much space and block Exinda from successful update..." but does not mark it as P1/SEV1/Critical or report an outage.
